verses.text: Sing aloud to God our strength; shout for joy to the God of Jacob!
verses.comment: This opening call to communal praise emphasizes God's strength and His relationship with Jacob's descendants, a reminder of the covenant He made with Israel. In the New Testament, such worship points forward to united praise in the Body of Christ (see Eph. 5:19).

verses.text: Raise a song; sound the tambourine, the sweet lyre with the harp.
verses.comment: Musical instruments accompany joyful worship. The use of instruments in worship has a long tradition, foreshadowing the liturgical beauty and reverence in Christian worship.

verses.text: Blow the trumpet at the new moon, at the full moon, on our feast day.
verses.comment: The sounding of the trumpet is closely associated with the sacred festivals, connecting worship with the liturgical calendar—the regular, communal rhythm of God's people.

verses.text: For this is a statute for Israel, an ordinance of the God of Jacob.
verses.comment: God institutes certain liturgical practices as binding statutes. These serve to unify God's people throughout generations and guide them in proper worship.

verses.text: He appointed it as a testimony in Joseph when he went out over the land of Egypt. I heard a language I did not know:
verses.comment: God's ordinances are rooted in historical deliverance—the redemption from Egypt is central to the faith. The reference to Joseph points to God's faithfulness through patriarchs and His mysterious works among the nations.

verses.text: I relieved his shoulder from the burden; his hands were freed from the basket.
verses.comment: God delivered His people from slavery—literally removing their burdens. This foreshadows Christ freeing humanity from the burden of sin (Matt. 11:28-30).

verses.text: In distress you called, and I delivered you; I answered you in the secret place of thunder; I tested you at the waters of Meribah. Selah.
verses.comment: God's deliverance is coupled with testing, as seen at Meribah. The references to God's voice in thunder point to God's transcendence and readiness to answer prayer, a theme deepened in the New Testament revelation of God's presence (John 12:28-29).

verses.text: Hear, O my people, while I admonish you! O Israel, if you would only listen to me!
verses.comment: God's loving rebuke is aimed at moving His people to true obedience. The heartfelt plea recalls the Shema (Deut. 6:4), emphasizing attentive and faithful listening.

verses.text: There shall be no strange god among you; you shall not bow down to a foreign god.
verses.comment: Exclusive worship of the one true God is central to the faith. Throughout salvation history, idolatry is seen as spiritual unfaithfulness, a reminder of the importance of true doctrine and enduring faith.

verses.text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt. Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
verses.comment: God alone provides for His people. Opening the mouth wide suggests a posture of trust and receptivity—a symbol fulfilled in the reception of God's word and grace, ultimately gathered in the unity of the one faith.

verses.text: But my people did not listen to my voice; Israel would not submit to me.
verses.comment: Human stubbornness leads to spiritual poverty. God’s desire is for loving obedience—a foundation for unity and the fullness of truth.

verses.text: So I gave them over to their stubborn hearts, to walk in their own counsels.
verses.comment: When God's people refuse to listen, He allows them to experience the consequences of their choices. This divine discipline calls us back to humility and true repentance.

verses.text: Oh, that my people would listen to me, that Israel would walk in my ways!
verses.comment: God’s yearning for obedience is a recurring scriptural theme. The path to blessing is through listening and walking in the way God has established, a way that is safeguarded and made clear by sacred tradition and teaching authority.

verses.text: I would soon subdue their enemies, and turn my hand against their adversaries.
verses.comment: Divine protection and victory are promised to those who remain faithful. This foreshadows the Church’s victory through Christ over all spiritual enemies (see Matt. 16:18).

verses.text: Those who hate the LORD would cringe before him, and their fate would last forever.
verses.comment: Those who oppose God cannot stand before His majesty. The permanence of their fate underscores the seriousness of rebellion and the necessity of persevering in the true faith.

verses.text: But he would feed you with the finest wheat, and with honey from the rock I would satisfy you.
verses.comment: The ‘finest wheat’ and ‘honey from the rock’ are not only physical blessings but also spiritual foreshadowings—anticipating the superabundant nourishment God provides for His people, fully given in the Bread of Life and the sweetness of the sacraments (see John 6:51).
